abstract.para: The system uptime tracking feature monitors when a client system is up. It works on an hourly basis—the system is considered up if it was running at any part of the given hour. The information is stored in &scc; (SCC) and Repository Mirroring Tool (RMT), and serves as a source for analytics purposes.

info.meta: How to monitor the uptime of a client system
Monitoring the uptime of a client system

listitem.para: All functionality is included in the suseconnect-ng package.
SCC has a visual representation for the uptime data and allows you to download the log files.
Updated GUI navigation when downloading a CSV file.
Introduced labels in the CSV output.
The version of the suseconnect-ng package has to be 1.13 or newer. Verify it by running suseconnect --version.
If the client system is behind RMT, the version of the rmt-server package on the RMT server has to be 2.17 or newer. Verify it by running rpm -q rmt-server.

sect1.title: Enabling the uptime tracking

step.para: Enable and start the suse-uptime-tracker timer.
Check if the service is running.
If you do not have a copy of the /etc/SUSEConnect file, create it by copying the example file.
Edit /etc/SUSEConnect and enable the uptime tracking.

After enabling the uptime tracking, the timer checks if the system is running every 15 minutes and stores the findings in a log file /etc/zypp/suse-uptime.log. The log file is uploaded to SCC/RMT by the suseconnect-keepalive service, which is triggered by the suseconnect-keepalive timer every 24 hours. Verify that the timer is running.

sect1.title: Viewing and downloading the data from SCC
sect1.para: The &scc; provides visualization of the uptime data for the last 14 days. The data is presented for individual systems in a histogram. You can monitor uptime trends and download CSV files with the uptime data for all owned servers and individual systems.

note.title: Only systems with uptime tracking enabled
note.para: Uptime data graphs and download capabilities are available only for systems that have reported uptime data. For systems that have not reported any uptime data, there are no uptime tracking widgets in the Usage section of SCC.

procedure.title: Viewing and downloading the uptime data

step.para: Log in to SCC at with your credentials.
In the left panel, select Organization and click the Systems tab to view the systems in your organization that have uptime data available in the last 14 days.

To download a CSV file that contains uptime data for all the systems in your organization, select System uptimes from the Download as CSV pull down. The pull down is only present if system uptime data is available.

figure.title: Download uptime data for all systems in an organization

textobject.phrase: Download uptime data for all systems in an organization

step.para: To view the uptime data histogram for a specific host, click its name from the list. In the host's Usage section, the 14-day histogram provides a detailed visual representation of the system uptime.
To download a CSV file containing the uptime data for the selected system, click the Download usage CSV button located above the histogram.

sect1.para: The uptime data retrieved from SCC has the following structure, where columns are separated by semicolons, for example:
If the above wget and curl commands include the include_hourly=true option, you receive more details about at what hours the host was up, for example:
sect1.screen: Id,Hostname,Online At Day,Online For Hours,Online At Hours,Labels 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-28,20,000011111111111111111111,"test" 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-29,5,000000000000000000111110,"test" 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-30,8,000000000000000111111110,"test" 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-06-01,7,000000000000000001111111,"test"
sect1.para: The columns have the following meaning:

listitem.para: All the systems managed by SCC/RMT are uniquely identified by a system ID generated during system registration in SCC/RMT.
The host name of the system.
The days on which the system was up at least for one hour. See the Online At Hours term explanation for deeper understanding.

Each bit represents the hour of the day. The leftmost position represents the zeroth hour of the day. 1 indicates that the system was up at any time during an hour, while 0 indicates that the system was offline.
Number of hours when the system was up during a given day.
List of custom labels. It is blank if you have not applied any labels to the systems being metered.

question.para: Why is the uptime data not available?

answer.para: On the client host, verify that the suseconnect-keepalive timer is running. It controls triggering the suseconnect-keepalive.service service automatically every 24 hours.

question.para: Was the host up between 9–10 a.m. on 2024-02-28?

answer.para: Retrieve the uptime data as described in . Open the data file and search for the line that includes 2024-02-27. Inspect that day's bit pattern, for example, 000011111111111111111111 and count up to the 10th digit (the bit starts with 0 a.m.) from left. The corresponding bit is 1, therefore the system was up between 9 and 10 a.m.

question.para: What is the total uptime and downtime of the host on 2024-05-28?

answer.para: The log line related to that date shows the bit pattern 000011111111111111111111. There are twenty 1's and four 0's in the pattern meaning that the host was up for twenty hours and down for four hours.

question.para: How many hours was the host up from May 28th to June 1st?

answer.para: To retrieve statistics about the host in a specific period, adjust the online_from and online_to parameters in the URL query mentioned in , for example:
answer.screen: &prompt.user;curl -X 'GET' \ -u'USERNAME:PASSWORD' \ 'https://scc.suse.com/connect/organizations/system_uptimes?include_hourly=true&system_id=16300735&online_from=2025-05-28&online_to=2025-06-01' \ -H 'accept: text/csv' Id,Hostname,Online At Day,Online For Hours,Online At Hours,Labels 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-28,20,000011111111111111111111,"test" 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-29,5,000000000000000000111110,"test" 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-30,8,000000000000000111111110,"test" 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-06-01,7,000000000000000001111111,"test"
answer.para: The sum of the Online For Hours column is 40, indicating the host was up for 3 40 hours.

question.para: How do I retrieve the uptime data for all hosts in my organization?

answer.para: For that purpose, omit the system_id, online_from and online_to parameters from the URL query, for example:
answer.screen: &prompt.user;curl -X 'GET' \ -u'USERNAME:PASSWORD' \ 'https://scc.suse.com/connect/organizations/system_uptimes?include_hourly=true \ -H 'accept: text/csv' Id,Hostname,Online At Day,Online For Hours,Online At Hours,Labels 16300735,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-28,20,000011111111111111111111,"test" 16300736,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-29,5,000000000000000000111110,"lab" 16300736,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-30,8,000000000000000111111110,"lab" 16300737,localhost.localdomain,2025-05-30,7,000000000000000011111111,"prod" 16300737,localhost.localdomain,2025-06-01,7,000000000000000000111111,"prod"
answer.para: As you can see, the list includes system IDs from different hosts.
